div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Petition of Gwoo Shee Ah Look, alien, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. } No. 2647 Return to Petition and Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of Said Court:
Comes now Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, and for answer to the Writ of Habeas Corpus, issued herein, and for answer to the petition filed herein, states as follows:
I. That he denies each and every allegation of the petition save and except what is hereinafter specially admitted.

II. As to the allegations set forth int he first paragraph of page one, ending at "within the United States for many years", he has not knowledge and information thereof sufficient to form a belief, and therefore denies the same.
III. As to the allegations set forth in the second paragraph, he admits those ending at the words "which is unknown to your petitioner", that he denies the reast of the allegation in said paragraph.

IV. As to allegations set forth in paragraph three, he
has not knowledgte and information thereof sufficient to form a belief, and therefore denies the same.

V. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph four, he admits the allegations beginning at the words "detained, confined, and restrained" and ending at the end of the paragraph; and denies the allegations in said paragraph down to the said words "detained" etc.
VI. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph five, he admits same.
VII. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph six, he admits the same.
VIII. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph seven, he admits the same.
IX. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph eight, he denies each and every one thereof.

X. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph nine, he has not the record of the hearing in his possession, and is therefore unable to say whether the statement as to the testimony taken by the Government was correct or not; that if this statement is correct, he will admit same, and if on arrival of the transcript it is incorrect, he will deny same; that the transcript of the hearing will be marked "Exhibit A" and is made a part of this return upon its arrival.
XI. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph ten, he denies the same.
XII. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph eleven, he has not knowledge and information thereof sufficient to form a belief, and therefore denies the same.
XIII. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph twelve, he has not knowledge and information thereof sufficient to form a belief, and therefore denies the same.
XIV. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph fourteen, he has not knowledge and information thereof sufficient to form a belief, and therefore denies the same.
XV. As to the allegations set forth in paragraph fiften, he has not knowledge and information thereof sufficient to form a belief, and therefore denies the same.

XVI/ That wherever he has denied the statement as to what testimony took place before the Commissioner, he will withdraw same if, on examination of the original record of the hearings, it is shown that the petition for Habeas Corpus correctly gives the testimony that was had before said Commissioner.
And for a further and separate answer and return to said application for a writ of habeas corpus, and for further return to said writ, said Henry M. White alleges as follows:

I. That a hearing was had before the Commissioner and the petitioner was ordered deported, as is set forth in paragraphs five and six. That after the decision of the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, he sent a warrant of deportation from Washington, and the alien was delievered by Inspector Watkins, of Portland, to the defendant answering herein, for the purpose of deporting her.
II. That the hearing was had according to the Deportation Law of Feburary 20, 1907, and every right provided for under this Act was given the petitioner.

III. That though the evidnece as to the prostitution of the petitioner might have been conflicting, there was strong and substantial evidence showing that she was a prostitute; that she should therefore be deported and the petition ans writ herein be dismissed.
Wherefore said Henry M. White prays the above entitled court that the said writ be dismissed and the application and petition therefor be denied.
In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington
In the Matter of the Petition of Gwoo Shee Ah Look, alien, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Return to Petition and Wrt of Habeas Corpus.
Filed in the U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, Northern Division JAN 17 1914 Frank L. Crosby, Clerk, By EML Deputy.
